title: What should my band name be? (We have a ukulele, drummer, singer, and pianist) - Quora

response.answer_text: First name that came to my mind was PUDS, the acronym for your instrument names. But that’s a horrible choice unless you really want to stay small with a niche audience! I agree with Mike Walker that you’re best to start from the audience’s perspective. For my book No Brown M&Ms!, which features entrepreneurial lessons learned from rock legends, we researched the whole band name thing. Hands down, again and again, the most successful bands had/have names that are short, easy to spell, memorable, not too weird, and often relevant to their music/audience — a perfect example being Metallica. Relevance might be more literal, like the death metal band Cannibal Corpse, but it might also just be the feel of the name, like the ‘80s/’90s alt-rock band Trip Shakespeare. Fans of both bands relate to the names as evocative of what to expect from the music. Switch the names between those bands, and it’s just wrong on every level. Of course, not all successful bands’ names have relevancy to their fans or genre — not much about “U2″ speaks to its music or fans’ taste — but if not, the name will usually have the other traits. You can’t get any more short, easy to spell, memorable, and not weird than “U2.” I think there’s an argument to be made that they wouldn’t have been as successful if they’d retained their original moniker: The Larry Mullen Band. Would you have been excited in 1980 to tell your friends about this incredible new band you just discovered called… The Larry Mullen Band? Word of mouth wouldn’t have traveled so well, and there would’ve probably been accompanying apologies: “You need to check out this great band from Ireland. Their name sucks, but they’re really good.” Essentially, it’s all about branding. And just as businesses can learn from successful rock bands, rock bands can learn from successful businesses. Would Coca-Cola have become world famous and mega-successful if it’d had a more common name of the times — like Dr. Winston’s Magical Brain Elixir? Ultimately, if you have to go with one trait above the others, go with shorter (as long as it’s not too weird). Our research found this to be the most distinguishing feature among successful bands. As you go from names with one word to two to three to four, the incidence of success goes markedly down. Five Finger Death Punch and Clap Your Hands Say Yeah are extremely notable exceptions, and probably partly because they’re more appropriate for their time. It’s safe to say those names would’ve tanked in 1975. Typically, once you go to three words or more, people start abbreviating — e.g., ELO, ELP, and OMD. (In fact, the bands above are often referred to as just Death Punch or CYHSY.) Even two-word band names often get shortened by fans, such as Led Zeppelin being referred to as simply Zeppelin or Zep, and Iron Maiden being just Maiden. All this said, if your goal is to stay small, quirky, and indie, then (like Trip Shakespeare) you will probably not be harmed by choosing a name that violates the “rules” I’ve mentioned. If you were Duke and His Uke, playing in small clubs or touring regionally, the name isn’t likely going to hinder your game. Your own marketing and promotion and tenacity (and music) will be far more of a factor. And thus you have all the oddball small-time names like Uncle Johnny’s Rotten Kids, George Washington Lied, or The Painful Balls. They’re great for niche success, but you’ll be in a bind if larger potential success presents itself. An example that comes to mind is the 1980s alt-rock band Sex Maggot. They started to gain some traction and were stepping up into bigger success. But then a club owner in New England refused to put their name on his marquee, throwing a wrench into their tour plan. Realizing they’d probably picked a bad name for the big picture, they became Goo Goo Dolls (from an old advertisement they saw for a “Goo Goo Doll”). I don’t think it’s a stretch to say they would’ve never gone on to massive 1990s popularity and sales if they’d stuck to Sex Maggot. Finally, for trivia’s sake and interesting reading, here’s a great run-down of band name origins: List of band name etymologies - Wikipedia. (Although I’ve been referring to rock band names because that’s what I know best, my points still seem to apply to non-rock bands and acts, from what I’ve seen in other genres.) Thanks for the A2A!

You should call it one of the below: Strum ThurmondThe Dukes of UkePlinkers and DrinkersStrings and ThingsUkeless InformationI Have a Plinking ProblemWe’re Not Israel Kamakawiwo'oleSomewhere Over the DranoLook, Ma, No Band!Softloud and the Four String Death MarchI Got Played Last NightKarma Karma Karma Karma Karma Kawiwo’oleWe’re Not Zooey DeschanelI Just Uked All Over a CopFestering Corpse OozeHey, It’s the Thirties!And if you’re in the Los Angeles area, you should call me, because I play autoharp.
There’s a lot in a name: the name has to resonate with you, a quirk about your band, a play on words, or something that reveals the core of who you are(or not).
Ukeclectic (pronounced uke-clectic), because that’s kind of an eclectic instrumentation. I like it, though. Good luck!
Well, I'm not sure what genre you are going for, but let me give you a few! Lemon heads, Pastel Punk, When the Sun Rises, Tomorrow is Today.
Uncle Slinky You know you love it!
Lord of the Ukulele Hamsters Chordhead Taking Back November ~You’re welcome.
I think ‘The Ukulelist, Drummer, Singer, and Pianist’ would be perfect.
PiaukDsin. Careful: Use a UKu go to jail!
whatever you want it to be.
